Ob Bioshock Infinite meine erwartungen erfüllen oder gar übertreffen konnte erfährt ihr in dieser Review.(Diese Review wird keine Spoiler enthalten.)

Story: Es ist 1912. Wir spielen Booker Dewitt, der als Privatdetektiv hohe Wettschulden hat. Um sich wieder reinwaschen soll er in die Wolkenstadt Columbia reisen um dort ein bestimmtes Mädchen namens Elizabeth zu finden und sie nach New York zu bringen. Es gibt sehr viele Magic Moments, aber mehr wird nicht verraten. Als Schlusswort zur Story Ich kann euch versichern das Ende ist eines der besten Enden das ich jemals gesehen hab.

Grafik: Bei der Grafik hatte Ich anfangs wirklich meine bedenken ob mir der neue Grafikstil gefallen wird, aber als ich es ich denn gespielt habe bin ich doch zu dem Entschluss gekommen das der Grafikstil sehr stimmig zur Atmosphäre passt.

Sound: Die Soundqualiät ist sehr gut. Der Soundtrack ist zwar nicht so Facettenreich, aber die Kampfthemes so wie die ruhigen Musikstücke sind wirklich wundervoll. Die Musik ist ein echtes Highlight in dem Spiel.

Gameplay: Das Gameplay ist sehr gut gelungen. Während der linearen Reise mit Elizabeth Sammelt man wie im ersten Bioshock seine Plasmide auf und hat somit Fähigkeiten die, die Schussgefächte frischer auf einen wirken lassen. Plasmide lassen sich nur mit Salz(dem EVE aus dem ersten Bioshock) benutzen. Ansonsten kann man immer Zwei Waffen gleichzeitig tragen, welche man bei Waffenautomaten upgraden kann. In Columbia gibt es noch überall Schienen die verschiedene Orte verbinden auf denen man sich mit einer "Skyhook" einklinken kann und dann auf den Schienen gleiten kann. Es gibt noch sehr viele Boni zu finden. Leute die vieles erkunden wollen können dies tun und sehr viele Hintergrundinformationen sammeln.

Atmosphäre: Die Atmosphäre in Bioshock Infinite ist Fabelhaft. Columbia wird einem sehr gut vorgestellt. Man kann vieles erkunden was die Welt lebhafter darstellt.

Fazit: Bioshock Infinite hat meine Erwartungen vollkommen übertroffen, macht sehr vieles richtig und ist fast schon das perfekte Spiel im Shootergenre. Es ist sehr Abwechslungsreich und sehr kreativ  und wenn man merkt das "Infinite" kein sinnloser Namenszusatz ist, weiß man dass es etwas ganz besonderes ist. 
Mein Spiel des Jahres 2013!

Wertung: 10/10 Punkten

BIG HIT and small miss.  This game is both incredibly engaging, rich, and addictive.  Its well written and highly polished in many areas.  From the moment you enter Columbia till the expected 'unexpected' ending you will be at the edge of your seat.  And THATS my only critism for this game.  You are engaged right up to the end...and then just left a bit wanting.  Perhaps the DLC will cure this feeling of wtf you have at the end but it seems to be more a feature by the game developers then a flaw to them.  I also strongly miss the effects of my moral choices having an affect on the game play but in the end this is a minor gripe as well.  Really my only big critism is that the game is so engaging and so thrilling as you play it that when your done...well...your done.  There is the 1999 mode or a bunch of completionists achievements to collect on multiple playthroughs but that ripping and exciting game play of the first play through just...doesn't change.  Nothing new to really see, no choices to go and try the other path, and no multiple endings based on a moral leaning during the game.  So if you want to play a great game ONCE then this is for you...if you want something worthy of 9 playthroughs and branching choices then your looking at the wrong game.

¿Es Bioshock Infinite el Shooter del 2013?, no tengo dudas al respecto, con un nivel de evolución notable a sus anteriores entregas, y con un diseño atractivo y maravilloso que lo mantienen distante a cualquier otro shooter, son la base para posicionarlo como el mejor de su género este año. Sus gráficos no se pueden tratar como lo "último en generación", pero su atractivo audiovisual llena completamente esa falta. Gran historia, grandes personajes, muy buena dificultad y por sobretodo muy entretenido, es un juego altamente recomendado y sin duda uno de los mejores del 2013
es muy buen juego me entretengo jugando
Dat twist ending.

A highly memorable game and well worth your time. The story is well told, but it has some head scratching moments. The graphic, sound and music is stunning. The best enemy is the dangerous Heartbreaker, which made me scream and laugh. Collecting items which is scattered around the levels is time consuming and not fun to do at all. The combat becomes repetitive after a few hours of gameplay (mostly due to the same kind of enemies). Some bugs and glitches (suddenly quitting the game, objectives stuck throughout the entire game, giving an order to lockpick a safe but never happened). It lags sometimes even though my specs are way higher than the recommended specs. There are choice making decisions in this game, but it's far off the scale compared to the great moments in Stanley Parable and Spec Ops: The Line. This game is recommended, because there is no other game out there like it. Its strengths are the storytelling and the exotic environments. If you are looking for a great shooter, it has a few amazing sequences.

This game is amazing! It has that bioshock feel for sure, it's nice and balanced, and the ending, It was kinda hard to move after the ending of burial at sea (Great dlc). I've almost gone through this game 2 times, and it just keeps piling up more and more as you play it. If i'm right, it took me atleast... 8 hours to complete the singleplayer campaign the first time. The weapons sound really nice, Especially the shotgun and the rapid fire volley gun (Forgot the name). Here's a trick with the shotgun btw, Hold reload and fire and you'll shoot a bit faster. The burial at sea DLC was really nice. It felt like bioshock 1&2 with the vending machines, gene banks, weapons, and of course, the big daddies. In that DLC was confusion too. You'll know what i mean if you play the normal campaign then the DLC. I'd give this game a definate 10/10.

A solid entry in the Bioshock series, the combat is the best in Infinite out of all of them. The story is solid, and it is fun to explore the nooks and crannys of Columbia. The game world was obviously crafted with care, though there are certain aspects that seem rushed out the door or out of place, especially at the end of the game. This dosen't ruin the experience however, and the game is a solid addition to any game library. I wish a greater variety of weapons and powers were avaliable earlier in the game.

Ein grandioses Spiel mit einer anspruchsvollen, intellektuellen und höchst erfrischenden Story. Auch wenn sich hier von den Vorgängern Bioshock 1 & 2 sowohl storytechnisch als auch das Setting betreffend entfernt wird entsteht trotz allem das bekannte und liebgewonnene Bioshock-Feeling. Dadurch dass Infinite diegetisch vor den ersten Teilen angesiedelt ist und die interessanten Spielereien mit Quantenphysik und -theorie ist es zudem nicht erforderlich, die Vorgänger gespielt zu haben um der Story folgen zu können.

Klare Kaufempfehlung sowie Anwärter auf Spiel des Jahres 2013.
Прекрасная игра. Очень атмосферно.

Game started out fantastic. Beautiful design, engaging themes, and entertaining situations. Fast forward to around the sixth hour of gameplay: redundant fights, annoying combat, unsatisfying powers, and (if playing on the highest difficulty) maddeningly frustrating fights with the Handyman. Seriously, if you disagree with me, try to beat the Handyman in one of the last fights on the hardest difficulty. There is nothing gratifying with the combat structure in this game.

Most reviews that I see gush over the game's story. Look, I get it: the idea of alternate universes, travel between them, and consequences of choices that can alter future choices is intriguing. Unfortunately, getting to these themes involved introducing multiple, underdeveloped characters that just seemed like more and more names being thrown at you. The games storyline with the revolution and the overall "alternate universes" theme conflicted and annoyed me for the latter part of the game. Fighting animated patriot machines was... dumb. It seemed like the developers felt they could get away with putting any stupid scenario in the game just because in one of the infinite universes it was possible.

I would recommend many other games over Bioshock Infinite. I strongly feel that its success is a product of strong advertising. Not GOTY in terms of atmosphere, story, and combat mechanics.

First, I'll mention that [i]Bioshock Infinite[/i] is gorgeous and absolutely worth playing, especially at the sale prices it's been going for lately. The drawback is that it's a bit more incoherent than [i]Bioshock[/i], and the setting isn't quite so sharp, but it's still an amusement park worth visiting. If anything it can be accused of, it's overambition, not quite focusing as sharply as earlier [i]Shock[/i] games.

Even with the traditional FPS mechanics, though, it's still one of the more innovative and original titles this year, and is definitely worth making time for. The DLC [i]Burial at Sea[/i] is definitely worth playing through - though it's quite short, it at least benefits from a strong budget, not recycling as much as it could have from either [i]Bioshock[/i] or [i]Bioshock Infinite[/i].

One of the games that'll define this year, though it lives somewhat in the shadow of its forebears.

Puedo decir mil cosas buenas de este juego, pero lo mejor es que lo probéis vosotros.

Still it is a great game.

[h1] A Good and sincere, no BS review of Bioshock Infinite [/h1]

(read underlined text for a tl;dr)

played this for the first time a long while ago, and I just keep coming back to it even when the replayability isn't really there.
This game is stupid fun. The combat is snappy and gratifying, [u]some of it's mechanics are easily in my top favorites of any action game [/u]. The story demands attention, but any effort from the player to understand it is rarely rewarded.

[h1] How does it fare against the first game? [/h1]

It's more streamlined, literally on rails (get it? play it and you will), but as a result I believe it's better since the devs got to design the whole flow of the experience throughout; they called the shots, but still allowed you some freedom to switch things up a bit. Still, this had a negative impact on replayability; once you did the thing™ you don't feel like doing it again differently because the outcome stays the same. [u]It offers the same experience to every player[/u] is what I'm trying to say, which is not that big of a deal unless you choose so.

[h1] Visuals and Sound [/h1]

Game is gourgeous, [u]the graphics are stylized and thus they stand the test of time[/u] (some day, The Last of Us's realism will look old, that game came out the same year as this one) a feast to the eyes I tell you. Aesthetically unique, get ready to be fully immersed in a pintoresque world you've never seen before or since, just like the first game, but this time they leave very little to the imagination, there's no guessing what life was like before things went down, you get to see it first hand.

Sound design is distinctively unique. You'll recognise and remember specific sounds from this game, even things that show in other games don't sound like this (guns/melee/UI and menus/Etc.). There's some [b]Adaptive Music[/b] during combat (easily noticeable at the end of an encounter) which is A+ btw, like every song on this game, [u]they both set the mood and capture the time period perfectly[/u]. They even got appropiate covers from famous 80's to 90's pop songs like Girls Just Wanna Have fun, Everybody Wants to Rule The World, Tainted Love, and even Fortunate Son which is from the late 60's.

[h1] Plot [/h1]

I won't lie. [b]It drags[/b]. It starts off simple then immediately goes bonkers speed and expects you to care about characters you've never interacted with before and only knew about for 20 minutes. No exaggeration there.
My recommendation is to just ignore the mumbo jumbo and enjoy the moment to moment interactions with the two main characters, these are well written.
So how complicated does it get? [u]Let me just say this: There's parallel universes.[/u] That should tell you everything.
The last 3 hours you'll be wishing things went back to how they used to be before they got all scientific on you. There's plenty of 40 minute youtube essays out there explaining this game's ending, I'll tell you that much. The game tries to be all like Neil deGrasse Tyson's Twitter but only manages to come across as Jayden Smith's twitter. Both are cringe anyways.

[h1] Is this game for you? [/h1]

Did you play the first one? then you probably already bought this, if not, buy it anyway but understand that the plot, while dense, requires some prior knowledge to fully appreciate, but that shouldn't be the reason that keeps you from buying this.
[u]There's fun to be had here[/u]. If you like unique settings then this is it, chief. If you like those sci-fi/fantasy/drama Netflix original series then this might also be for you. If you like fun FPS's not bound by realism that give you many tools to use creatively, this already should be one of your faves. [u]The Gameplay design alone is 20/10.[/u]

Also, the DLC is pretty good and accentuates what the base game had going on: There's a gameplay focused combat-in-waves DLC and a Story DLC split into 2 parts with lots of new content and fan-service. A nice send-off for a nice Franchise.

This should've been GOTY when it released.

This game shows that the gaming industry is coming close to creating their "Citizen Kane". Gameplay is fantastic, characters are emotionally engaging, and it brings a significant message, much like classic literature, that is open to the interpretations of the player. Truly a game that those who research media will point to in the future as  the beginnings of the maturing of the gaming industry...

...and yet f**king lot of fun ;)

However, before playing this game,  one should familiarize themselves with Poe's Law:
"Without a blatant display of humor, it is impossible to create a parody of extremism or fundamentalism that someone won't mistake for the real thing."
